VOL. XXI, NO. 15.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 29, 1917.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WEEKLY MEETINGS INAUGURATED

BEGINS PREP SCHOOL CAMPAIGN

EX-PRESIDENT TO BE SPEAKER

FRESHMEN RUNNERS VICTORIOUS

Student Assemblies to Be Held in C. E.
Lecture Hall Every Wednesday—To
Be Under Joint Auspices of
Student Organizations.

Omicron Delta Kappa Committee Sends
Speakers to Park School—Others
to Go to Jefferson School.
Plans Developing.

William Howard Taft Will Deliver Commemoration Day Address at Hopkins on Washington's Birthday.
Forty-First Anniversary.

Carry Off Meet, 46 to 31—Smith,Bowen
and Melamet Star in Annual Games.
Senior Relay Team Wins for
Fourth Season.

The taass-meeting conducted in
the assembly hall of the Civil Engineering Building last Thursday
in all probability was the forerunner of a series of weekly meetings
to be held under the joint auspices
of the Athletic Association, the
Student Council, the Omicron
Delta Kappa and the Y. M. C. A.
It is planned to have these
meetings become a fixed institution, which will serve as a means
to keep interest in the various
Hopkins activities alive among
the students. A feature of future
assemblies will be the incorporation of the series of vocational
talks, begun last week by the Y.
M. C. A. with the address by Dr.
Birckhead. According to the present proposal, these talks will be
given under the joint auspices of
all the associations mentioned.
Another feature of the meetings, if the plan materializes, will
be discussion of various matters
by the students themselves. After
the address has been delivered by
the speaker of the day, and after
any announcements which either
the faculty or any student organization wishes to bring forth have
been read, the meeting will be
turned into an open forum, where
informal remarks on problems of
student interest may be made
from the floor.
Both President Goodnow and
Dean Brush have expressed themselves in hearty accord with the
general idea of such meetings.
Formal consent for the series
planned has not as yet been obtained, but there is every likelihood that the plan will soon be
officially indorsed.
The meeting last Thursday had
been requested by the Omicron
Delta Kappa and was to have
been presided over by the dean.
Dr. Brush's illness, however, rendered this impossible.
At the present time, it seems
unlikely that the meetings can be
held at any time which conflicts
with the regular class hours. It
is felt, however, that the sacrifice
of half an hour will be made willingly by the great majority of the
student body.
The details of the plan have
not as yet been fully worked out
by the various organizations, but,
once that it has been cifficially indorsed, no difficulty is anticipated
in completing all the necessary arrangements. Especial care is to
be taken to see that the length of
the meetings is restricted to a
reasonable time.

At the Park School last Monday
morning the committee which has
in charge the advertisement of
Hopkins in the preparatory,and
high schools began its active work.
Those who are writing the
speeches, which are to be placed
in the hands of different delegations of undergraduates to be delivered in as many of the Maryland schools as possible before
next June, had an opportunity on
this occasion to try out their material before a most attentive and
appreciative audience. The advantages of the academic department of our University were presented by Reuben Oppenheimer.
Randolph Smith, in a clear and
concrete manner, told the story of
the Hopkins Technical School and
explained the advantages and
promising position which this department occupies among institutions of its kind. The last speech
was made by Frederick P. Hall,
chairman of the committee, who
described the Homewood buildings and the various forms of
student activities which are engaged in by the Hopkins students.
This last talk was illustrated by
lantern slides showing buildings,
views of the campus, and representative athletic teams.
From the manner in which the
subjects were presented and from
the cordial reception which the efforts of the delegation received at
the hands of the students and officers of the school it is to be inferred that this newly inaugurated branch of service to our
Alma Mater is to have results of
significant proportions.
In all the advances which the
committee has made to various
school authorities its offers have
been accepted with the utmost
eagerness and commendation. The
only obstacle which now blocks
the pathway to the fullest measure of success is the preoccupation of those who are asked to
take part in the work. The approach of examinations, the
steady increase in the activity of
the athletic organizations, and a
general attitude of conservatism
on the part of many otherwise
capable workers, all are counteracting tendencies to the success
of the work.
On Wednesday the second attack in the campaign is to be
staged at Jefferson School. The
delegation will consist of Robert
G. Merrick,Henry Baker and John
C. Knipp, while another public-

The Commemoration Day exercises of the forty-first anniversary
of the founding of Johns Hopkins
University will be held on the
morning of February 22. The address of the day will be delivered
by ex-President William Howard
Taft, now Kent professor of law
at Yale University.
The assembly room in the Civil
Engineering Building at Homewood is not large enough to accommodate the crowd expected to
be present at these ceremonies,
hence the Lyric Opera House has
been secured. The exercises will
be held there at 11 o'clock on the
morning of February 22.
Hopkins has always been singularly fortunate in obtaining wellknown and talented men to speak
at the Commemoration Day exercises. Last year, Dr. Wellington
Koo, the Chinese Minister at
Washington,delivered the address,
and the year before, Dr. Nicholas
Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was the chief
orator.
Mr. Taft has not as yet announced the subject of his speech,
nor have all the arrangements for
the exercises been completed. The
request to take part in the exercises was dispatched to Mr. Taft
some time ago, but, until a few
days ago, he did not feel at liberty to announce definitely that
he would be able to accept.

The annual field and track meet
held by the sophomore and freshman classes last Saturday in the
old Howard street gymnasium resulted in a well-won victory for
the freshmen, the final score being 46 to 31.
Beverly Smith, captain of the
1920 Class team, was the star of
the contest, winning first in both
the 220-yard and 440-yard dashes,
and second in the 30-yard dash.
His time in the quarter was
582/5 seconds, which is a remarkably good cage record. The second highest point winner was
Bowen, a graduate of Polytechnic,
also a member of the freshman
class. Bowen won first in the
mile and 880-yard run.
Melamet was the individual
star of the sophomores in the
dashes, achieving second places in
the high jump, the 220 and 440yard dashes. In the last two
events he gave Smith a close rub,
being in the lead for a couple of
laps in the 440, but Smith passed
him in the final spurt.
The freshmen started off with a
flourish that gave them both
places in the 30-yard dash, Bratt
being first and Smith second.
Melamet and Weech ran best for
the sophomores.
The 880 was one of the best
races of the day, being in doubt
until the crack of the pistol on
the last lap, when Bowen, displaying remarkable reserve force,
dashed to victory a few yards
ahead of his sophomore opponent.
The agility of Melamet seemed
at first to presage success for him
over Parkman ('20) in the high
jump. The bar rose higher and
higher but at 5 feet 4 inches the
sophomore failed to clear, and
Parkman was granted a hard-won
victory. Parkman again showed
his prowess in the 30-yard hurdles
in which he tied with Defandorf
('20).
The final event--the sophomorefreshman relay race—was won by
1920. The summary:

"Barn" to Have Opening After Exams.

In spite of the completion and
present use of the Student Activities Building, it was definitely decided by the University authorities to postpone the official opening and dedication until after the
mid-year examinations. It is the
hope of the committee in charge
to make this reception a fine affair, and it was thought unwise
to attempt ally action which
might interfere with or be interfered with by the examinations.
According to present plans, it is
desired to get the alumni out in
force. Speeches will be made by
both past and present students.
spirited senior has consented to
facilitate matters by means of his
motorcar. Immediately after the
examinations as full a schedule of
engagements will be arranged as
the support of the students warrants, and the committee expects
its effectiveness to increase steadily with the accumulation of experiences and helpful suggestions.

o'clock in the large lecture hall of
the Mechanical and Electrical
Building, Mr. Thomas W. Hind,
who is connected with the Crown,
Cork and Seal Co., and who is
interested in a new method of
operation of the Diesel engine,
will address the Hopkins Engineering Society on that subject.
The talk will be given on the evening of the first day of the second term and the members of the
society are looking forward to Mr.
Hind's talk with interest.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 29, 1917.
The Honor System.

The reason why the value of so
many institutions — those of the
broader social order, as well as
those of the colleges and universities — is not appreciated, is because the existence of those institutions is so often taken as a matter of granted. The fact that the
honor system prevails at Hopkins
is regarded by upper-classmen as
an obvious commonplace—as obvious as is the inevitability of examinations themselves, and it is
accepted by freshmen as a part of
the general order into which they
have been introduced; yet in
many colleges and universities the
honor system is as yet unknown,
and it has been carried to the
point at which it exists in Hopkins only by a comparative few.
The idea that college men are,
by nature, possessed of enough
integrity to fulfill the little printed statement pasted across the inside of the first page of Hopkins'
examination books, considered as
an abstract theory, is by no means
a radical one. Nevertheless, the
fact remains that, at many American colleges, classes are treated
on the theory that the only thing
which prevents them from reading
off notes from their cuffs or from
having a general consultation as
to the way in which a certain
question should be answered is
the presence of a vigilant professor at their elbow. The exact
causal relation between espionage

and attempted transgression has
never been exactly determined,
but the conviction is coming to be
stronger and stronger that the
best way to insure a man's honesty is to assume that honesty before you begin.
It should be thoroughly understood by freshmen that they are
under no obligation to sign the
pledge affixed to their examination papers. Nor if, for any reason, they do not wish to sign it,
will it be assumed for an instant
that their refusal is necessarily
due to an inability to meet with
its requirements. It is the policy
of the Student Council to urge all
to sign the slip, more as a matter
of form than anything else, as an
appreciation of the courtesy on
the part of the faculty which the
honor system involves; but even
if it is not so formally attested,
the fact that "assistance has
neither been given nor received"
is always regarded as a matter
of course.
Hopkins has quite a few problems to solve during the next few
years, but how to obtain the honorableness of its student body is
not one of them.
The Eternal Question.

Just why so many men who, in
other respects, could be regarded
as typical Hopkins products
should insist upon designating the
University which they attend by
the name of "school" is a question
which has not as yet been satisfactorily answered. That they do
so, and that the habit is not confined to the freshmen, may be affirmed by listening to the most
casual conversation in the basement or in the hall. "I was almost late for school today";
"School is getting harder"; "I
wish the school would abolish examinations" — the examples are
myriad.
Is there no way in which the
entire student body can be made
to realize the fact that they have
left their preparatory days behind
them? The Baltimore City College is a school, the Polytechnic
Institute is a school, Gilman's,
and Jefferson's, and all the rest
are schools, but Hopkins is a university. If the thing were only
an evidence of slang, it would be
understandable and excusable, but
it isn't—it is the evidence of an
unmistakable provincialism, the
remnant of an atmosphere which
should have been discarded—and
hasn't been.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 29, 1917.
ARMORY MEET TO SET NEW MARK
Yale, Cornell and Princeton to Send
Delegations of Runners—South Atlantic Events Restricted to
Former Participants.

According to present indications the Armory Meet this year,
which will be held on Saturday,
February 24, will be one of the
best ever staged by the joint Athletic Associations. During the
absence of the Fifth Regiment on
the border the Hopkins half of the
Joint Games Committee, consisting of Corner, Duncan and Davis.
have arranged for the open events
and for the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association
championships.
Yale, Cornell and Princeton, as
well as other
colleges,
schools, clubs,universities,
and Y. M. C. A.'s of
the vicinity of Baltimore have signified their intention of sending
groups of athletes to compete in
the open events. The South Atlantic events will, of• course, be
closed to Hopkins, Virginia,
Georgetown and the other members of the association.
There will be several relay races
between the great rival colleges
of the East, as well as the annual
South Atlantic relay, closed to the
association. Then, too, there will
be a fraternity relay race, from
which all,men on the track squad
will be debarred, thus making it
strictly a novice event.
Such an event was held several
years ago, in which Phi Gamma
Delta came out victorious. Six
fraternities have announced that
they will be represented by
teams. They are:' Beta Theta Pi,
Phi Kappa Psi, Alpha Delta Phi,
Phi Gamma Delta; Kappa Alpha
and Pi Kappa Chi.
As usual, there will be individual medals given to each man
finishing first, second and third in
each event, and to each member of
the victorious relay teams. Besides this a handsome team trophy
will be given to the association
scoring the greatest number of
points in the meet.
The list of events is as follows:
Open Handicap Events — 100-yard
dash, 220-yard dash, 440-yard dash,

100-yard low hurdles, 880-yard run,
one-mile run, pole vault, running high
jump, 16-pound shot-put.
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association Championships, open only
to athletes from the following colleges:
Johns Hopkins University, University
of North Carolina, Georgetown University, Georgia School of Technology, St.
John's College, Virginia Polytechnic
Institute, Richmond College, Univergity of Virginia, Washington and Lee
University, George Washington University, Catholic University (scratch)
—1-mile relay, 1-mile run, 100-yard
dash, 100-yard low hurdles, 220-yard
dash.
Interscholastic Events — 100 - yard
dash, 440-yard dash, 880-yard run.
Relay ,Races (one mile each)—Open
to universities, colleges, schools, athletic clubs, Y. M. C. A.'s and regiments.
Relay races (one-half mile each),
age and weight of each contestant must
be given—Open to schools, athletic
clubs and Y. M. C. A.'s.
Closed to Members of the Fifth
Regiment (no athlete registered from
any club or organization other than
the Fifth Regiment will be permitted
to enter these events)—Military relay,
handicap events, 100-yard dash, 800yard run.

THE JOHNS HO PKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 29, 1917.

TELLS HOW TO CHOOSE VOCATION
Dr. Birckhead informs Students That
They Must Study Their Own Possibilities—Mr. Bonaparte
Next Speaker.

At a mass-Meeting of students
in the Donovan Room, last Wednesday noon, Dr. Hugh Birckhead,
of the Immanuel P. E. Church,
spoke on "The Principles Which
Should Guide One in Choosing a
Profession." This address was
the first of a series of "Life-Work
Talks," which will be given at
the mass-meetings on Wednesday
noons for the next several weeks.
The meeting was presided over
by President Goodnow. Doctor
Goodnow expressed his approbation of the plan of having student mass-meetings at regular
hours and spoke of the importance
of the series of talks which was
about to be begun. He then introduced Doctor Birckhead.
Doctor Birckhead began his
talk by contrasting the principles
for guiding his life as set down
by Decoq at the age of 21 and the
ones generally held by the young
men of today.
He then presented the unique
problem arising from the great
European war which confronts
all young men, and spoke of the
trained organized will of Germany
which is permitting her to keep
the whole world at bay. He urged
upon the students to learn to subordinate themselves, to feel themselves a part of one great whole.
He then spoke of the the various
elements which should guide a
young man in choosing his career,
and in the first place warned
against the element of compensation, which should always be the
last considered.
•
"First," he said, "we must consider our temperament; we must
know ourselves, find out what we
are naturally fitted to do and do
it with all our might. We must
consider our ability, our relation
to our fellow-men, and lastly, our
relation to God. We must look
into our hearts, find out who we
are, fasten ourselves to our fellowmen and discover how we can help
them."
The speaker for next week's
meeting will be Mr. Charles J.
Bonaparte, former Secretary of
the Navy and- Attorney-General
of the United States. Mr. Bonaparte's subject will be "The University Trained Man, and His
Civic Responsibility."

At a meeting of the 1917 Hullabaloo Board last Friday, final
plans for fife book were rounded
into shape. The work is progressing even better than was expected, and Editor-in-Chief Straus
promises that this year's Hullabaloo will be one of the most representative the University has ever
had.
At the meeting, various writeups were discussed. These, for the
most part, have been completed,
and it is confidently hoped by the
board that the first part of the
book will be in the hands of the
printer soon after the examinations.
Announcement was made at the
meeting that the proofs of the
photographs will be received in
about 10 days. Each individual
will then be allowed to select the
pose which seems to him to best
represent his particular type of
manly beauty. His choice must
be put into the hands of Art Editor C. W. Black, together with a
snapshot of himself.
The individual biographies must
be handed in at the same time as
the proof and the snapshot.
The board wishes it to be definitely understood that no prints
will be sent to the engraver until
the money for the plate ($1.50 in
the case of individuals) has been
paid.

The officers of the Rifle Club
have been successful in their efforts
to have the Club entered in the
intercollegiate matches held under
the auspices of the War Department in Washington. The intercollegiate matches begin the week
of January 29, the first match of
which must be shot by the twentyfourth of this month. These
matches are open to all undergraduate members of the Club,
the selection of the team being determined by the calibre of the
shooting done in previous trials.
Ten men shoot in each match,
the five highest scores counting
for the team score. According to
the new regulations, each man of
the team shoots twenty shots, ten
standing and ten prone, at a range
of fifty feet.
Many of the large colleges met
last year will be on this year's
schedule. Lieutenant Elliot has
offered his services as judge. The
shooting will be held on whatever
nights the old Richmond Armory
can be procured, probably Thursday or Friday.
The Baltimore City League will
soon start its second series. The
Hopkins team now stands the
highest in one of the two divisions
of this league. As there has not
as yet been any matches between
the divisions, the championship
match is creating much interest.

At the tryouts for the privilege
of competing for the Adams
Medal, to be awarded at the Inter-Class Debate on March 3,
Mitchell B. Carroll, Maurice
Glick and Corydon P. Gowman,
Jr., were selected.
The tryouts were exceptionally
well attended, and the contest
was very close. The contest for
the Adams Medal is only open to
members of the sophomore class.
It was decided last week, by a
flip of the coin, as is the custom,
that the juniors were to take the
affirmative of the subject in the
Inter-Class Debate, and the seniors the negative. The subject is
"Resolved, That, constitutionality
waived, legislation providing for
the compulsory arbitration of
labor disputes in public utilities
and prohibiting all strikes and
lockouts in such utilities should
be enacted."
Reuben Oppenheimer has been
designated by Doctor French as
the captain of the senior team,
and Morton K. Rothschild as the
captain of the juniors. The advisors for the two teams have
not as yet been selected, nor has
the order or speakers on either
side been determined.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 29, 1917.

WEEKLY MEETINGS INAUGURATED

BEGINS PREP SCHOOL CAMPAIGN

EX-PRESIDENT TO BE SPEAKER

FRESHMEN RUNNERS VICTORIOUS

Student Assemblies to Be Held in C. E.
Lecture Hall Every Wednesday—To
Be Under Joint Auspices of
Student Organizations.

Omicron Delta Kappa Committee Sends
Speakers to Park School—Others
to Go to Jefferson School.
Plans Developing.

William Howard Taft Will Deliver Commemoration Day Address at Hopkins on Washington's Birthday.
Forty-First Anniversary.

Carry Off Meet, 46 to 31—Smith,Bowen
and Melamet Star in Annual Games.
Senior Relay Team Wins for
Fourth Season.

The taass-meeting conducted in
the assembly hall of the Civil Engineering Building last Thursday
in all probability was the forerunner of a series of weekly meetings
to be held under the joint auspices
of the Athletic Association, the
Student Council, the Omicron
Delta Kappa and the Y. M. C. A.
It is planned to have these
meetings become a fixed institution, which will serve as a means
to keep interest in the various
Hopkins activities alive among
the students. A feature of future
assemblies will be the incorporation of the series of vocational
talks, begun last week by the Y.
M. C. A. with the address by Dr.
Birckhead. According to the present proposal, these talks will be
given under the joint auspices of
all the associations mentioned.
Another feature of the meetings, if the plan materializes, will
be discussion of various matters
by the students themselves. After
the address has been delivered by
the speaker of the day, and after
any announcements which either
the faculty or any student organization wishes to bring forth have
been read, the meeting will be
turned into an open forum, where
informal remarks on problems of
student interest may be made
from the floor.
Both President Goodnow and
Dean Brush have expressed themselves in hearty accord with the
general idea of such meetings.
Formal consent for the series
planned has not as yet been obtained, but there is every likelihood that the plan will soon be
officially indorsed.
The meeting last Thursday had
been requested by the Omicron
Delta Kappa and was to have
been presided over by the dean.
Dr. Brush's illness, however, rendered this impossible.
At the present time, it seems
unlikely that the meetings can be
held at any time which conflicts
with the regular class hours. It
is felt, however, that the sacrifice
of half an hour will be made willingly by the great majority of the
student body.
The details of the plan have
not as yet been fully worked out
by the various organizations, but,
once that it has been cifficially indorsed, no difficulty is anticipated
in completing all the necessary arrangements. Especial care is to
be taken to see that the length of
the meetings is restricted to a
reasonable time.

At the Park School last Monday
morning the committee which has
in charge the advertisement of
Hopkins in the preparatory,and
high schools began its active work.
Those who are writing the
speeches, which are to be placed
in the hands of different delegations of undergraduates to be delivered in as many of the Maryland schools as possible before
next June, had an opportunity on
this occasion to try out their material before a most attentive and
appreciative audience. The advantages of the academic department of our University were presented by Reuben Oppenheimer.
Randolph Smith, in a clear and
concrete manner, told the story of
the Hopkins Technical School and
explained the advantages and
promising position which this department occupies among institutions of its kind. The last speech
was made by Frederick P. Hall,
chairman of the committee, who
described the Homewood buildings and the various forms of
student activities which are engaged in by the Hopkins students.
This last talk was illustrated by
lantern slides showing buildings,
views of the campus, and representative athletic teams.
From the manner in which the
subjects were presented and from
the cordial reception which the efforts of the delegation received at
the hands of the students and officers of the school it is to be inferred that this newly inaugurated branch of service to our
Alma Mater is to have results of
significant proportions.
In all the advances which the
committee has made to various
school authorities its offers have
been accepted with the utmost
eagerness and commendation. The
only obstacle which now blocks
the pathway to the fullest measure of success is the preoccupation of those who are asked to
take part in the work. The approach of examinations, the
steady increase in the activity of
the athletic organizations, and a
general attitude of conservatism
on the part of many otherwise
capable workers, all are counteracting tendencies to the success
of the work.
On Wednesday the second attack in the campaign is to be
staged at Jefferson School. The
delegation will consist of Robert
G. Merrick,Henry Baker and John
C. Knipp, while another public-

The Commemoration Day exercises of the forty-first anniversary
of the founding of Johns Hopkins
University will be held on the
morning of February 22. The address of the day will be delivered
by ex-President William Howard
Taft, now Kent professor of law
at Yale University.
The assembly room in the Civil
Engineering Building at Homewood is not large enough to accommodate the crowd expected to
be present at these ceremonies,
hence the Lyric Opera House has
been secured. The exercises will
be held there at 11 o'clock on the
morning of February 22.
Hopkins has always been singularly fortunate in obtaining wellknown and talented men to speak
at the Commemoration Day exercises. Last year, Dr. Wellington
Koo, the Chinese Minister at
Washington,delivered the address,
and the year before, Dr. Nicholas
Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was the chief
orator.
Mr. Taft has not as yet announced the subject of his speech,
nor have all the arrangements for
the exercises been completed. The
request to take part in the exercises was dispatched to Mr. Taft
some time ago, but, until a few
days ago, he did not feel at liberty to announce definitely that
he would be able to accept.

The annual field and track meet
held by the sophomore and freshman classes last Saturday in the
old Howard street gymnasium resulted in a well-won victory for
the freshmen, the final score being 46 to 31.
Beverly Smith, captain of the
1920 Class team, was the star of
the contest, winning first in both
the 220-yard and 440-yard dashes,
and second in the 30-yard dash.
His time in the quarter was
582/5 seconds, which is a remarkably good cage record. The second highest point winner was
Bowen, a graduate of Polytechnic,
also a member of the freshman
class. Bowen won first in the
mile and 880-yard run.
Melamet was the individual
star of the sophomores in the
dashes, achieving second places in
the high jump, the 220 and 440yard dashes. In the last two
events he gave Smith a close rub,
being in the lead for a couple of
laps in the 440, but Smith passed
him in the final spurt.
The freshmen started off with a
flourish that gave them both
places in the 30-yard dash, Bratt
being first and Smith second.
Melamet and Weech ran best for
the sophomores.
The 880 was one of the best
races of the day, being in doubt
until the crack of the pistol on
the last lap, when Bowen, displaying remarkable reserve force,
dashed to victory a few yards
ahead of his sophomore opponent.
The agility of Melamet seemed
at first to presage success for him
over Parkman ('20) in the high
jump. The bar rose higher and
higher but at 5 feet 4 inches the
sophomore failed to clear, and
Parkman was granted a hard-won
victory. Parkman again showed
his prowess in the 30-yard hurdles
in which he tied with Defandorf
('20).
The final event--the sophomorefreshman relay race—was won by
1920. The summary:

"Barn" to Have Opening After Exams.

In spite of the completion and
present use of the Student Activities Building, it was definitely decided by the University authorities to postpone the official opening and dedication until after the
mid-year examinations. It is the
hope of the committee in charge
to make this reception a fine affair, and it was thought unwise
to attempt ally action which
might interfere with or be interfered with by the examinations.
According to present plans, it is
desired to get the alumni out in
force. Speeches will be made by
both past and present students.
spirited senior has consented to
facilitate matters by means of his
motorcar. Immediately after the
examinations as full a schedule of
engagements will be arranged as
the support of the students warrants, and the committee expects
its effectiveness to increase steadily with the accumulation of experiences and helpful suggestions.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 29, 1917.
The Honor System.

The reason why the value of so
many institutions — those of the
broader social order, as well as
those of the colleges and universities — is not appreciated, is because the existence of those institutions is so often taken as a matter of granted. The fact that the
honor system prevails at Hopkins
is regarded by upper-classmen as
an obvious commonplace—as obvious as is the inevitability of examinations themselves, and it is
accepted by freshmen as a part of
the general order into which they
have been introduced; yet in
many colleges and universities the
honor system is as yet unknown,
and it has been carried to the
point at which it exists in Hopkins only by a comparative few.
The idea that college men are,
by nature, possessed of enough
integrity to fulfill the little printed statement pasted across the inside of the first page of Hopkins'
examination books, considered as
an abstract theory, is by no means
a radical one. Nevertheless, the
fact remains that, at many American colleges, classes are treated
on the theory that the only thing
which prevents them from reading
off notes from their cuffs or from
having a general consultation as
to the way in which a certain
question should be answered is
the presence of a vigilant professor at their elbow. The exact
causal relation between espionage

and attempted transgression has
never been exactly determined,
but the conviction is coming to be
stronger and stronger that the
best way to insure a man's honesty is to assume that honesty before you begin.
It should be thoroughly understood by freshmen that they are
under no obligation to sign the
pledge affixed to their examination papers. Nor if, for any reason, they do not wish to sign it,
will it be assumed for an instant
that their refusal is necessarily
due to an inability to meet with
its requirements. It is the policy
of the Student Council to urge all
to sign the slip, more as a matter
of form than anything else, as an
appreciation of the courtesy on
the part of the faculty which the
honor system involves; but even
if it is not so formally attested,
the fact that "assistance has
neither been given nor received"
is always regarded as a matter
of course.
Hopkins has quite a few problems to solve during the next few
years, but how to obtain the honorableness of its student body is
not one of them.
The Eternal Question.

Just why so many men who, in
other respects, could be regarded
as typical Hopkins products
should insist upon designating the
University which they attend by
the name of "school" is a question
which has not as yet been satisfactorily answered. That they do
so, and that the habit is not confined to the freshmen, may be affirmed by listening to the most
casual conversation in the basement or in the hall. "I was almost late for school today";
"School is getting harder"; "I
wish the school would abolish examinations" — the examples are
myriad.
Is there no way in which the
entire student body can be made
to realize the fact that they have
left their preparatory days behind
them? The Baltimore City College is a school, the Polytechnic
Institute is a school, Gilman's,
and Jefferson's, and all the rest
are schools, but Hopkins is a university. If the thing were only
an evidence of slang, it would be
understandable and excusable, but
it isn't—it is the evidence of an
unmistakable provincialism, the
remnant of an atmosphere which
should have been discarded—and
hasn't been.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 29, 1917.
ARMORY MEET TO SET NEW MARK
Yale, Cornell and Princeton to Send
Delegations of Runners—South Atlantic Events Restricted to
Former Participants.

According to present indications the Armory Meet this year,
which will be held on Saturday,
February 24, will be one of the
best ever staged by the joint Athletic Associations. During the
absence of the Fifth Regiment on
the border the Hopkins half of the
Joint Games Committee, consisting of Corner, Duncan and Davis.
have arranged for the open events
and for the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association
championships.
Yale, Cornell and Princeton, as
well as other
colleges,
schools, clubs,universities,
and Y. M. C. A.'s of
the vicinity of Baltimore have signified their intention of sending
groups of athletes to compete in
the open events. The South Atlantic events will, of• course, be
closed to Hopkins, Virginia,
Georgetown and the other members of the association.
There will be several relay races
between the great rival colleges
of the East, as well as the annual
South Atlantic relay, closed to the
association. Then, too, there will
be a fraternity relay race, from
which all,men on the track squad
will be debarred, thus making it
strictly a novice event.
Such an event was held several
years ago, in which Phi Gamma
Delta came out victorious. Six
fraternities have announced that
they will be represented by
teams. They are:' Beta Theta Pi,
Phi Kappa Psi, Alpha Delta Phi,
Phi Gamma Delta; Kappa Alpha
and Pi Kappa Chi.
As usual, there will be individual medals given to each man
finishing first, second and third in
each event, and to each member of
the victorious relay teams. Besides this a handsome team trophy
will be given to the association
scoring the greatest number of
points in the meet.
The list of events is as follows:
Open Handicap Events — 100-yard
dash, 220-yard dash, 440-yard dash,

100-yard low hurdles, 880-yard run,
one-mile run, pole vault, running high
jump, 16-pound shot-put.
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association Championships, open only
to athletes from the following colleges:
Johns Hopkins University, University
of North Carolina, Georgetown University, Georgia School of Technology, St.
John's College, Virginia Polytechnic
Institute, Richmond College, Univergity of Virginia, Washington and Lee
University, George Washington University, Catholic University (scratch)
—1-mile relay, 1-mile run, 100-yard
dash, 100-yard low hurdles, 220-yard
dash.
Interscholastic Events — 100 - yard
dash, 440-yard dash, 880-yard run.
Relay ,Races (one mile each)—Open
to universities, colleges, schools, athletic clubs, Y. M. C. A.'s and regiments.
Relay races (one-half mile each),
age and weight of each contestant must
be given—Open to schools, athletic
clubs and Y. M. C. A.'s.
Closed to Members of the Fifth
Regiment (no athlete registered from
any club or organization other than
the Fifth Regiment will be permitted
to enter these events)—Military relay,
handicap events, 100-yard dash, 800yard run.

THE JOHNS HO PKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 29, 1917.

TELLS HOW TO CHOOSE VOCATION
Dr. Birckhead informs Students That
They Must Study Their Own Possibilities—Mr. Bonaparte
Next Speaker.

At a mass-Meeting of students
in the Donovan Room, last Wednesday noon, Dr. Hugh Birckhead,
of the Immanuel P. E. Church,
spoke on "The Principles Which
Should Guide One in Choosing a
Profession." This address was
the first of a series of "Life-Work
Talks," which will be given at
the mass-meetings on Wednesday
noons for the next several weeks.
The meeting was presided over
by President Goodnow. Doctor
Goodnow expressed his approbation of the plan of having student mass-meetings at regular
hours and spoke of the importance
of the series of talks which was
about to be begun. He then introduced Doctor Birckhead.
Doctor Birckhead began his
talk by contrasting the principles
for guiding his life as set down
by Decoq at the age of 21 and the
ones generally held by the young
men of today.
He then presented the unique
problem arising from the great
European war which confronts
all young men, and spoke of the
trained organized will of Germany
which is permitting her to keep
the whole world at bay. He urged
upon the students to learn to subordinate themselves, to feel themselves a part of one great whole.
He then spoke of the the various
elements which should guide a
young man in choosing his career,
and in the first place warned
against the element of compensation, which should always be the
last considered.
•
"First," he said, "we must consider our temperament; we must
know ourselves, find out what we
are naturally fitted to do and do
it with all our might. We must
consider our ability, our relation
to our fellow-men, and lastly, our
relation to God. We must look
into our hearts, find out who we
are, fasten ourselves to our fellowmen and discover how we can help
them."
The speaker for next week's
meeting will be Mr. Charles J.
Bonaparte, former Secretary of
the Navy and- Attorney-General
of the United States. Mr. Bonaparte's subject will be "The University Trained Man, and His
Civic Responsibility."

At a meeting of the 1917 Hullabaloo Board last Friday, final
plans for fife book were rounded
into shape. The work is progressing even better than was expected, and Editor-in-Chief Straus
promises that this year's Hullabaloo will be one of the most representative the University has ever
had.
At the meeting, various writeups were discussed. These, for the
most part, have been completed,
and it is confidently hoped by the
board that the first part of the
book will be in the hands of the
printer soon after the examinations.
Announcement was made at the
meeting that the proofs of the
photographs will be received in
about 10 days. Each individual
will then be allowed to select the
pose which seems to him to best
represent his particular type of
manly beauty. His choice must
be put into the hands of Art Editor C. W. Black, together with a
snapshot of himself.
The individual biographies must
be handed in at the same time as
the proof and the snapshot.
The board wishes it to be definitely understood that no prints
will be sent to the engraver until
the money for the plate ($1.50 in
the case of individuals) has been
paid.

The officers of the Rifle Club
have been successful in their efforts
to have the Club entered in the
intercollegiate matches held under
the auspices of the War Department in Washington. The intercollegiate matches begin the week
of January 29, the first match of
which must be shot by the twentyfourth of this month. These
matches are open to all undergraduate members of the Club,
the selection of the team being determined by the calibre of the
shooting done in previous trials.
Ten men shoot in each match,
the five highest scores counting
for the team score. According to
the new regulations, each man of
the team shoots twenty shots, ten
standing and ten prone, at a range
of fifty feet.
Many of the large colleges met
last year will be on this year's
schedule. Lieutenant Elliot has
offered his services as judge. The
shooting will be held on whatever
nights the old Richmond Armory
can be procured, probably Thursday or Friday.
The Baltimore City League will
soon start its second series. The
Hopkins team now stands the
highest in one of the two divisions
of this league. As there has not
as yet been any matches between
the divisions, the championship
match is creating much interest.

At the tryouts for the privilege
of competing for the Adams
Medal, to be awarded at the Inter-Class Debate on March 3,
Mitchell B. Carroll, Maurice
Glick and Corydon P. Gowman,
Jr., were selected.
The tryouts were exceptionally
well attended, and the contest
was very close. The contest for
the Adams Medal is only open to
members of the sophomore class.
It was decided last week, by a
flip of the coin, as is the custom,
that the juniors were to take the
affirmative of the subject in the
Inter-Class Debate, and the seniors the negative. The subject is
"Resolved, That, constitutionality
waived, legislation providing for
the compulsory arbitration of
labor disputes in public utilities
and prohibiting all strikes and
lockouts in such utilities should
be enacted."
Reuben Oppenheimer has been
designated by Doctor French as
the captain of the senior team,
and Morton K. Rothschild as the
captain of the juniors. The advisors for the two teams have
not as yet been selected, nor has
the order or speakers on either
side been determined.
